bestBHT.bht: The Levite, an inferior minister of the law, seemed to go even farther than the priest in coming near to the wounded man and observing his condition before passing by. While the priest had specific duties in the temple, the Levite's role was to render assistance to the priests. It is clear that the Levite's actions fell short of showing mercy. This reminds us that under the law, no mercy can be expected, and even under the Gospel, an imperfect obedience cannot justify us in the sight of God.

Henry Alford: 32.] The Levite, the inferior minister of the law, did even worse; when he was at the place, he came and saw him;—came near, and then passed, as the other.
Albert Barnes: The special duty of the priest was 'to offer sacrifice' at the temple; to present incense; to conduct the morning and evening services of the temple, etc."
The office or duty of the 'Levites' was to render assistance to the priests in their services.

It is remarked by critics, here, that the expression used does not denote, as in the case of the priest, that he accidentally saw him and took no farther notice of him, but that he came and looked on him more attentively, but still did nothing to relieve him.
Marvin Vincent: Seeming to imply that the Levite went farther than the priest in coming near to the wounded man, and, having observed his condition, passed on.
The Levite went farther than the priest in coming near to the wounded man.
Having observed his condition, [the Levite] passed on.
Philip Schaff: An inferior minister of the law, engaged in the service of the temple.
The nearest English equivalent for both the Levite’s office and conduct would probably be found in the word ‘beadle.’
John Gill: No mercy is to be expected from thence: the law makes no abatement in its demands, nor any allowance for the fall and weakness of man.
Nor is it become milder under the Gospel dispensation; nor will it accept of an imperfect, though sincere obedience, in the room of a perfect one.
The deeds of the law, performed by sinful men, are impure and imperfect; and were they pure and perfect, they would be unprofitable, and could not justify in the sight of God from former sins.

bhtAttempts.bht: The Levite, an inferior minister of the law, seemed to go even farther than the priest in approaching the wounded man, observing his condition, and then passing by without offering any assistance. While the priest had specific duties in the temple, the Levite's role was to render assistance to the priests in their services. Although some suggest that the Levite looked on the wounded man more attentively but still did nothing to help, it is clear that his actions fell short of showing mercy. This passage reminds us that under the law, no mercy can be expected, and even under the Gospel, an imperfect obedience cannot justify us in the sight of God.

The Levite, an inferior minister of the law, went farther than the priest in coming near to the wounded man and observing his condition, but still did nothing to help. While the priest had specific temple duties, the Levite's role was to assist the priests. This highlights that even under the Gospel, imperfect obedience cannot justify in the sight of God. The law makes no allowances for human weakness, and past sins cannot be justified by impure and imperfect deeds.

The Levite, an inferior minister of the law, seemed to go even farther than the priest in coming near to the wounded man and observing his condition before passing by. While the priest had specific duties in the temple, the Levite's role was to render assistance to the priests. It is clear that the Levite's actions fell short of showing mercy. This passage reminds us that under the law, no mercy can be expected, and even under the Gospel, an imperfect obedience cannot justify us in the sight of God.

The Levite, an inferior minister of the law, seemed to go even farther than the priest in coming near to the wounded man and observing his condition before passing by. While the priest had specific duties in the temple, the Levite's role was to render assistance to the priests. It is clear that the Levite's actions fell short of showing mercy. This reminds us that under the law, no mercy can be expected, and even under the Gospel, an imperfect obedience cannot justify us in the sight of God.

The Levite, who was an inferior minister of the law, went even farther than the priest in coming near to the wounded man and observing his condition but did nothing to relieve him. While the priest had specific duties in the temple, the Levite's role was to assist the priests. This passage highlights the lack of mercy expected from the law and reminds us that an imperfect, though sincere, obedience cannot justify us in the sight of God.
